loans.name: Najwa

texts.en:
On your way to the Chouf you can find in Sharoun village a small grocery shop. When you go in, you can smell the tasty odor of hot bread. If you talk to the person in front, you can see the smile of Najwa S.. If you order a 'mankoushé' (thyme baked on bread), you will definitely ask for another. Apparently Najwa has a secret recipe she got from her father who was a pastry cook.

"Once a customer told me he came especially to Sharoun for my 'manakish'," Najwa told us. Since her food is famous in the region, Najwa needs an oven for baking bread so as to be ready for all her customers' orders. That way she can also avoid health complications for herself. US$ 300, the amount Najwa is asking to borrow, is the price of the used oven she needs to have to improve her small business. Najwa is part of a group with 5 other women from the same village. Her group's name is 'Al Eman' which means faith. The group loan is for a self-chosen group of women, living in vulnerable conditions, mostly in rural areas. Group lending is based on incremental increase of the loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that is encourages the collaborative approach in the borrowing community. The group loan is a very powerful tool for economic empowerment of women.

loans.use: To buy an oven

loans.name: Juana Cleofe

texts.es:
Juana is a young woman who has found the best way to fulfill her role as mother to her three beloved young children. For the last 10 years she has worked selling yogurt. She was assisted by a cousin who taught her the craft, using milk as the principal ingredient. In the beginning, before she could make her product at home, she had to purchase milk from various people and dairies. As she saw that the cost of these purchases was very high, she decided to save her money to purchase a small milk cow. Over time, and through her the hard work caring for the animals, her cow had a calf, which increased her livestock population. Currently, she has three cows, which allow her to produce a greater quantity of yogurt and to increase her profit. Juana is very satisfied with what she has been able to accomplish; nevertheless, there are many more goals that she would like to reach. Because of this, she has decided to learn to make higher quality yogurt, and to establish a dairy at her home. She has the strength and the desire, and because of this she is requesting a $500 loan for the purchase of an additional cow. With your support we will be able to help Juana continue to work for the betterment of her family.

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva volunteer.

Juana es una mujer joven que vió la mejor manera de cumplir a cabalidad su rol de madre con sus tres pequeños hijos a los cuales ama con todas sus fuerzas. Decidió hace 10 años dedicarse a la venta de yogurt por medio de una prima que le ayudó y le enseñó a elaborarlo teniendo como insumo principal a la leche; antes de desarrollar esta actividad en casa tenía que comprar la leche de diversas personas o establos y observando que el costo que invertía era muy alto decidió ahorrar para comprarse una pequeña vaquita lechera. Con el tiempo y el inmenso esfuerzo que le dedicó al cuidado de su nueva aliada su vaquita tuvo un becerrito y así aumento la población en su establo.Actualmente tiene tres vacas las que le han permitido incrementar la cantidad del yogurt que elaboraba además de sus ganancias.Juana se siente muy satisfecha por lo que ha logrado hasta ahora sin embargo es consciente de que aún tiene muchas metas que desea llegar a alcanzar por ello decidió capacitarse en la elaboración de yogurt con estándares de calidad e inició el proyecto de establecer una planta lechera en casa; los esfuerzos y las ganas la acompañan y a razón de estos anhelos solicita un préstamo de 500 dólares para adquirir una vaca más. Con tu aporte haremos que Juana siga trabajando por el bien y el desarrollo de su familia.

loans.use:
Purchase of a cow

Compra de una vaquita.

loans.name: Akwasi

texts.en:
Akwasi, 30, sells clothing and cell phone units from a wooden structure on the roadside. He has great relationship with his customers. Although his business is strong, the government may demolish his shop in order to build a highway. If that is the case, he plans to move into a metal container at a nearby location.

Akwasi is optimistic about the move. He believes that his new location will generate more profits. First, he needs to save more money, and the loan will help him do so. He hopes to expand his stock by purchasing more pairs of jeans. This will increase his profits which will be used for his new store as well as taking care of his four-year-old son.

Akwasi is a member of the lending group, Hope. This group guarantees the loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing jeans.

loans.name: Nazakat

texts.en: Nazakat is a 32-year-old woman who runs her livestock in the small village in the Imishli regions. She started her business in 2003 when she purchased her first calf. Now her business is going well, and she purchase calves and sells it to the local bazaar traders for meat production. Meat is a very popular product all across Azerbaijan and people use meat in their everyday life. Nazakat married and has one son. Breeding animals is the only one source of income in the family and she needs to expand her business and increase financial resources. She needs 1100 USD to purchase one milk cow for an estimated cost of 700 USD and one calf for an estimated cost of 400 USD.

loans.use: Going to purchase one milkier cow and one calve

loans.name: Jesús

texts.es:
Jesús has been devoted to selling steamed tacos for more than 19 years. Given that his parents did the same thing, he knew some things about tacos and how to make them since a young age. After he separated from his wife and was left to take care of three children, this is how he started this business to keep his family going and to provide for his three children. In the beginning, he sold tacos outside his home. But now, he has an eatery where more people can come to buy his food.

However, Jesús thinks that the place needs a better look. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of $925 which will be paid back in installments over 6 months. With this loan, Jesús will be able to buy tables, chairs for the customers who sit to eat more comfortably. With your help, Jesús will be able to support his family.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

Jesús se ha dedicado al negocio de venta de tacos al vapor hace más de 19 años. Puesto que sus padres se dedican a lo mismo y desde pequeño ha conocido los trucos para prepararlos. Después de que se separó y quedó a cargo de sus tres hijos. Fue cuando comenzó a luchar más por sacar adelante este negocio para poder brindarles estudio a los tres. En un inicio vendía los tacos fuera de su casa. Pero ahora está en un local en donde hay más gente que le pueda comprar.

Sin embargo Jesús considera que a el local le hace falta una mejor vista. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $925 que está seguro los podrá pagar en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Jesús podrá comprar mesas, sillas para que sus clientes se sientan más cómodos. Con tu ayuda Jesús podrá sacar a su familia adelante.

loans.use: to buy tables and chairs

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema is 27 years old. She is married with four children, ages two, five, seven, and eleven. She sells bites and she started her business in 2003. Everyday, she works from 7:00 am to 1:00 pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $65.00 from her sales.

Neema has already successfully completed a loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She would now like a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Moustapha

texts.fr:
Mr. D. is a craftsman who is specialized in canvas work and who does business at Moussanté, the main market in Thiès. In his workshop, he has a few machines that he uses to sew handbags. The finished products are transported for sale to the capital, Dakar, and the rest are sent to his brother in Gambia. As is the case with all businesses of this type, one must be able to acquire the raw materials necessary to be able to fill all of the orders.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mr D. est un artisan spécialisé dans la tapisserie dans le grand marché de « Moussanté » à Thiès. Il dispose dans son atelier de quelques machines avec lesquelles il coud les sacs à mains. Le produit fini est acheminé dans la capitale Dakar où une bonne partie est écoulée et le reste est envoyé chez son frère en gambie. Comme dans toutes les activités de ce genre, il faut pouvoir assurer l’acquisition de matières premières pour pouvoir honorer les commandes.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials to fill his orders

loans.name: Marta Lorena

texts.es:
Mrs. Marta Lorena M. M. is a very hard working person who works in her general store and thus provides for her family and the necessities of her home. She is a lady that has been able to maintain her two small children through her investment in her business which she attains with a lot of sacrifice,

In spite of the difficult financial situations that she has been through, she has been able to improve her business thanks to the loans that she received from Ceprodel which she has used to purchase goods for her store. With these loans she has improved the variety of her products and has been able to provide better living conditions for her children who need them so much. For this reason she is once again hoping to benefit from a loan for the purchase products to stock her general store.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Marta Lorena M. M. es una persona muy esforzada que se dedica a su negocio de pulpería con el que abastece a su familia en las necesidades del hogar. Es una dama que ha logrado mantener a sus dos pequeños hijos gracias a la inversión que ha hecho en su negocio con mucho sacrificio.

A pesar de las difíciles situaciones económicas que ha atravesado, hoy en día ha mejorado su negocio gracias a los créditos otorgados por Ceprodel el que los ha utilizado para la compra de los productos para el negocio. Con estos créditos ha logrado ampliar mas sus productos y además le ha brindado mejores oportunidades de vida a sus hijos que tanto lo necesita. Por este motivo una vez mas espera en ser beneficiada con el crédito para la compra de los productos para surtir su pulpería.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for the general store

loans.name: Volver A Empezar Group

texts.es:
The Volver a Empezar group meets at 10:30 in the morning at the neighborhood center in Alto Lima. The members of the group are all very punctual, and with the help of the loan assistant they go to work on the domestic activities that each of them is responsible for.

Sadly, most of the members are separated from their husbands for many painful reasons, and so these women have taken on the role of heads of their households and are now responsible for their children’s wellbeing. That is the reason why the group is called Volver a Empezar, or “starting over again.”

The women prepare breakfasts and snacks for a living, which they sell as street vendors. Every day they set up their stands on different streets in the city, where they prepare tea, coffee, and hot chocolate, which they then sell along with empanadas, sandwiches, or simply bread. The women would all like their businesses to grow, and that is why they are applying for bigger loans—they will use the loans to rent small rooms where they can set up their businesses, which will guarantee them bigger sales. With increased income the women will be able to improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Chris Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

A las 10:30 de la mañana es la hora cuando la asociación “Volver a empezar” se reúne en el centro focal de Alto Lima, todo el grupo muy puntual, con la ayuda de su asistente de créditos, trabaja en las actividades internas de manera responsable.

Lamentablemente a la mayoría de las socias tuvieron que separase de sus parejas por muchos penosos motivos, lo que les llevo ser jefes de familia, encargándose del bienestar de sus hijos, es por eso que adquirieron la denominación de volver a empezar.

Se dedican a la preparación de desayunos y meriendas, esto lo realizan de manera ambulante, es decir, todos los días, arman su puesto en diferentes calles de la ciudad, y ahí mismo realizan la elaboración de té, café y cocoa acompañados con empanadas, sanguiches o simplemente pan. Tienen la esperanza de que sus negocios crezcan es por eso que solicitan mayores créditos para conseguir alquilar pequeños ambientes apropiados que les garantice mayores ventas y por consiguiente mayores ingresos para mejorar su calidad de vida.

loans.use: Applying for larger loans so they can rent small rooms that will guarantee bigger sales

loans.name: Nuriat

texts.en: Nuriat A. is a resident of Chanika, a town in the Dar Es Salaam region of Tanzania. She has been in business for the past seven years, with responsibility for a range of companies. Most recently, she has run a grocery store. The profits from this business have helped her put her kids in school and look after her family. She needs a loan to help her expand her business.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Mujeres Pensando En El Futuro Group

texts.en:
Ana Reyes is 57-year-old woman living in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. She lives with her husband, and she has three sons who are all married. Ana wants to start her own cafeteria, and she will use this loan to purchase sugar, coffee, tea, bread, butter, mayonnaise, ham, cheese, etc to run her business. She hopes to one day own a house and a motor vehicle to expand her business options.

Ana Reyes is part of a 15-person micro-bank, Mujeres Pensando en el Futuro, which means "Women Thinking in the Future.. Each woman has their own personal business but they unite to pay their loan as a group. The purpose of the group loan is to assist each other in case someone defaults. The Kiva loans will be divided among the group to pay back.

We thank you for your support on behalf of Ana, Mujeres Pensando en el Futuro group, and the entire team at Esperanza International.

loans.use: Ana Reyes will use this loan to purchase products for her cafeteria.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mr. Heng P., 41, and his wife, Mrs. Sophy Norng, 36, live along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1993 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Both children study at a local school.

Mr. Heng has been a remoque (motorbike with a trailer at the back) motor taxi driver along National Road Number Two for two years, while Mrs. Sophy has been farming for five years. Now Heng’s trailer is very old and broken. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a new trailer to replace the old one.

loans.use: To replace the trailer of his 'remoque' motor taxi.

loans.name: Ayéva Marie

texts.fr: Ayéva Marie K. est née le 20.04 1967 à Amégnran. Elle est marié et a sept (07)  enfants. Son mari est gérant d’une pharmacie villageoise. Ils habitent un petit village à l’intérieur du TOGO environ 70 km de Lomé la capitale appelé Zafi Hetchavi. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour faire le commerce du pétrole lampant qui est très recherché dans le village. Elle compte sur ce financement pour améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ayéva Marie K. was born on April 20, 1967, in Amégnran. She is married and has seven children. Her husband is the manager of the village pharmacy. They live in a little village called Zafi Hetchavi in the interior of Togo, about 70 km from the capital Lomé. Mme K. is requesting this loan to trade kerosene, which is in great demand in the village. She is counting on this financing to improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell kerosene

loans.name: Refija

texts.en:
Refija was born in 1951 and lives in a suburb of Gračanica in Bosnia.  She is married without children.  Refija raises cattle and earns roughly 350KM/month by selling milk and milk products.  (The equivalent of roughly $230USD.)  

In the past, Refija hoped to get a contract with a milk factory, but was unable to do so.  She now considers this to be a blessing, as the milk factory reportedly exploits its workers.  By selling milk and milk products to her friends and neighbors, she earns a much higher margin and has more control over her work.

Refija requests a 1,000KM loan from Women for Women International, which she will use to buy a new calf.  She will raise the calf into adulthood and earn additional income from its milk.  This is her second loan; the first was also used to buy a cow (pictured) and was paid back successfully.

loans.use: To purchase a cow.

loans.name: Preung

texts.en: Preung V., 35, is married and has three children, all of whom are still students. The family lives in the Prey Veng province of Cambodia. Preung and her husband earn income running a cow dealership, typically making about US$5 per day. She currently needs a loan of US$500 to be able to purchase additional cows for re-sale. Preung is confident that the loan will allow her to increase the daily income and help her better support her family.

loans.use: Purchase of cows for re-sale

loans.name: Marilú

texts.es: Marilú tiene 37 años, vive con su esposo y sus hijos. Hace 2 años se asoció con uno de sus sobrinos para instalar un taller de mecánica, su sobrino repara los carros de motor gasolinero y ella vende los repuestos necesarios, de esa manera y por la alianza han salido adelante para enfrentar los duros momentos de escasez económica, y tienen con este medio un ingreso más. Ella atiende su negocio preferentemente en las tardes donde más abunda la clientela, ahora su deseo es seguir adelante e implementar con más productos su vitrina de ventas. Es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP, y se compromete a ser una de las mejores clientes, siendo muy responsable en sus pagos. Con esta cantidad aumentará su capital de trabajo con la compra de más repuestos para autos.
texts.en:
37-year old Marilú lives with her husband and children. Two years ago she went into partnership with one of her nephews and opened a garage. Her nephew repairs engines, and she sells spare parts. Because of the partnership, everything is going well even in hard economic times, and they have increased their income. Marilú takes care of the business especially in the afternoons when there are more customers. Her wish now is to continue doing well and have more products to put in the display window. This is the first time that she has asked for a loan from MFP, and she promises that she will be a highly regarded client, always paying back her loan on time. With the money she will increase her working capital and buy more vehicle spare parts.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Rizvan

texts.en: Rizvan R. is 55 years old and lives in small village of the Saatli region in Azerbaijan. He is the father of five children, and his main work consists of breeding cattle. He has had this business for more than 15 years. This very good activity enables him to provide for the needs of his family. A very ambitious man, he would like to buy a greater number of cattle and build a farmhouse to house them in order to ensure their safety. Due to a lack of finances, he is asking for a loan of 1200 USD for the realization of this project. He promises to repay the loan in 15 months. When his dream is carried out, he will be able to have a greater source of revenue for his big family. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: purchase four calves

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Рустам Рахимбабаев  женат имеет 2 детей. Он работал водителем в одной из предприятий города, но настал пенсионный возраст и он ушел с работы. Ему предложили работать сторожем, но Рустам отказался так как оклад меньше и работы больше. У него дома есть 2 бычка и 2 овцы, он раньше развивал скот и продавал их. Теперь когда он без работный ему необходимо обеспечивать семью, он решил продолжить  продажей коров. Его жена поддерживает семейное хозяйство, она печет лепешки и в день имеет небольшой заработок, что позволяет им проживать и прикупать для дома продукты. Рустам и его сын ухаживать за скотом, они каждые 5 месяцев продают скот. В настоящий момент Рустаму необходим кредит, что бы расширить свой коровник ему брат посоветовал обратиться в Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Rustam R. is married and has two children. He worked as a driver in one of the companies in the city, but he has retired. He got an offer to work as a night watch, but Rustam has declined because the salary was too small and there was more work. At home he has two calves and two sheep, he used to breed and sell cattle. Now that he is unemployed and has to support his family he decided to keep selling animals. His wife is supporting the family household, makes breads and has a small daily income which helps them survive and buy food. Rustam and his son keep after the cattle and resell them every five months. Currently Rustam needs a loan to expand his cow house, his brother has advised him to come to MicroInvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr: Kossi T. est un jeune célibataire qui habite le quartier d’adidogomé, il fait comme commerce la vente des articles scolaires, il a associé à cela la photocopie, reluire et autres. Il fait ce commerce depuis 2007, il n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de wages il voudrait diversifier son commerce c’est pour cela qu’il demande auprès de wages un crédit. Il se débrouille bien et arrive à s’entretenir avec ce qu’il gagne.
texts.en:
Kossi T. is a young unmarried man who lives in the Adidogomé district. His commerce involves selling school items. He has included photocopies, book-binding, and more. He has been in this business since 2007. He has never been the recipient of a WAGES loan and would like to diversify his commerce. That’s why he’s asking for a loan from WAGES. He does well figuring things out and manages to take care of himself with what he earns.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school supplies and goods

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet A. is 34 years old. She is married and has five children, one male and four females. According to her, her first four children are currently in the basic school and the last one is yet to start school. Her husband is a cocoa and palm nut farmer. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a small farming community called Nkwateng in the Eastern Region of Ghana. The major occupation of the inhabitants, the men in particular, is farming. Most of the women, however, are into trading activities and palm oil production.  
Janet is also into the palm oil production business. She says she procures palm fruits from the local farmers and nearby farms. She adds the procured palm nuts to what she harvests from her husband’s farm. Janet distributes to customers who come to buy in bulk and retail. She wants a loan to procure palm fruits in bulk so that she can produce the oil in bulk and distribute to her increasing number of customers. It is her dream to help her husband give their children the best education.

loans.use: To procure palm nuts in bulk

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Married with three children, Jacob farms as well as raises pigs, goats, and fowls. Having joined GHAPE in 2008, he will use this loan to pay for the clearing and tilling of the farmland, and to purchase pigs, a goat, pig feed, and seeds for planting. Jacob is hopeful for the success of his business; he believes that he will have a good harvest this year, his pigs will continue to breed, and that his customer base will continue to grow.  

Like many fellow borrowers at GHAPE, Jacob and his family have faced many challenges in their lives: deaths in the family, deep poverty, long-term illness, and the inability to further their children’s education. However, with the help of this loan and the assistance of GHAPE’s services, Jacob has a brighter future. He will use the profits of this loan to save for family emergencies, pay for his children’s school fees, build a better house for his family, pay off his family’s hospital bills, and provide more food for his family!

Jacob appreciates GHAPE and Kiva lenders because of their assistance and services like the GHAPE workshops, and trainings on topics like loan management and family health. He also believes that because of these loans, he is now a better person.

Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase livestock and seeds and to clear and till his farmland

loans.name: Paulita

texts.en: A lady fisher, that is Mrs. Paulita G., 44 years old, of Migpangi, Bonifacio, Mis. Occ. She is married to a fisherman and blessed with two children. Her one child is now in Grade 6. She is a new member of PAGLAUM MPC – Tangub City under the PDP-LP Program. Her usual customers are their neighbors, the fish vendor in the market and sometimes the wholesaler. She joined PAGLAUM MPC because she believes that this institution can help them in crossing the bridge to success. Her future plan is to build a little Sari-sari store someday so that in times of bad weather, still they will earn in other ways by not depending merely on fishing. She also wants all her children to pursue their education until college. Now she is applying for PHP 3,000 as her first availment for the purpose of purchasing additional fishing equipment.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing equipment

loans.name: Judith Del Carmen

texts.es: La Señora Judith M. tiene 33 años de edad, casada, tiene dos hijos ambos estudiantes. Los planes para su familia es tener estabilidad económica y social. Reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino en la ciudad de Managua. Doña Judith tiene su pequeño negocio de variedad en el cual vende ropas y repostería, inicio vendiendo ropa en pocas cantidades y al pasar del tiempo inicio con las venta de repostería desde hace siete años tiene su negocio, las dificultades que ha encontrado son la falta de ingreso para invertir y la disminución en las ventas. Gracias al préstamo en Afodenic brindara mayores cantidades de producto y variedad en ellos con la compra de productos como: zapatos, perfumes, cosméticos, entre otros los cuales le generan mayores utilidades y brindarle mejor nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Mrs. Judith M., 33, is married with two kids, both students. Her plans for her family are to have economic and social stability. She lives in the Memorial Sandina neighborhood in the city of Managua. Mrs. Judith has her own variety store where she sells clothes and baked goods. She started selling clothes in small quantities and as time went by she began selling baked goods. She's had her business for seven years, and the difficulties she's encountered are the lack of income to invest and a drop in sales. Thanks to the loan from Afodenic she'll be able to get larger quantities of products and a greater variety, such as: shoes, perfumes, cosmetics, etc., which will offer her a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Todd Schmid, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of shoes, perfumes, and cosmetic products

loans.name: Unidas Por Fé Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha:  Guillermina Nicolasa R.., Justa Pastora S. y Digna Marina H..

El grupo solidario Unidas por fé está  conformado por las señoras: 

Doña Guillermina quien tiene una minipulpería en su casa, con el crédito logró comprar más productos para satisfacer las necesidades de los clientes. Ella es mujer casada con cuatro hijos, estas le ayudan en el negocio y así ella puede salir a comprar al mercado. Piensa que con el crédito logrará tener una pulpería más grande.Además vende de forma ambulante en Managua pero ofrece especies como : canela. Clavo de olor, manzanilla, etc.
Doña Justa Pastora, es una madre soltera que vive con sus dos hijos jóvenes, ellos le ayudan en su negocio que es la elaboración de escobas, este oficio lo aprendió de sus padres y ella se lo ha enseñado a sus hijos. Sueña con tener un buen taller y darle estudios secundarios a sus hijos.Vende el producto en Managua, Tipitapa y otros departamentos de la región.

Doña Digna Marina vende productos derivados del maíz como: pìnolillo, pinol, tortillas, tamales, etc., entrega a varios clientes que le compran al por mayor, con sus cinco hijos procesan estos productos en su casa, aprovecha la mano de obra familiar, sus hijos son jóvenes que estudian y ayudan en el negocio. Su esposo trabaja en taller de calzado y le ayuda a los gastos del hogar. Espera con el crédito comprar materia prima como Maíz, azúcar y leña para la cocina.
.
Viven en condiciones de vida humildes, llegaron a trabajar con Adim por una promoción que se hizo en la comarca y les gustó la forma de trabajar porque ellas no tienen garantías que dar para un crédito y en Adim se les dio confianza.
texts.en:
Photo from left to right: Guillermina Nicolasa R., Justa Pastora S. and Digna Marina H. The "Unidas por Fé" ("United by Faith") solidarity group is comprised of the following women: Guillermina has a mini-grocery store in her house. With loans, she was able to buy more products to satisfy her customers' needs. She is a married woman with four children who help her with her business so she can go out shopping in the market. With this loan, she would like to establish a larger grocery store. She also does mobile sales in Managua, offering spices like cinnamon, cloves and chamomile. Justa Pastora is a single mother who lives with her two young children. They help her with her business, which is making brooms. She learned this activity from her parents and she has taught it to her children. She dreams of having a good workshop and giving her children a secondary education. She sells her products in Managua, Tipitapa and other departments in the region. Digna Marina sells corn products like pìnolillo/pinol (a traditional sweet cornmeal and cacao-based drink), tortillas, tamales, etc. She brings them to various customers who buy in bulk. She makes these products at home with her five children, taking advantage of the family's manual labor capabilities. Her young children are in school and also help her with the business. Her husband works in a shoe shop and helps her with household costs. With this loan, she hopes to buy raw materials like corn, sugar and firewood for the kitchen. They live in humble conditions, and came to work with Adim because of a regional advertisement. They like this way of operating because before they couldn't get guaranteed credit, but Adim gave them confidence.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase spices and brooms

loans.name: Ronnie

texts.en:
Ronnie O. is from the village of Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 33 years old. Ronnie is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Ronnie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where he sells canned goods and daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. He also retails gasoline. Ronnie has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ronnie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to engage in business activities. Ronnie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ronnie is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP to be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ronnie from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family and for the renovation of his house. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Leonidas

texts.es:
Leonidas es socia del Banco Comunal Paloma.
Leonidas es soltera, tiene 46 años y 5 hijos, Leonidas viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde vende frutas y pollos para criar, y de las ferias compra cereales que vende en los diferentes mercados. Además Leonidas tiene un kiosco cerca del hospital en donde vende bebidas.
Leonidas necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de gaseosas, leche y papel.
Lo sueños de Leonidas son que sus hijos culminen sus estudios y salir adelante.
texts.en:
Leonidas is a member of the Paloma (The Dove) Communal Bank. She is 46 years of age, single and has five children. Leonidas travels to the different fairs in the region where she sells fruits and chickens for raising and breeding. She also buys grains at the fairs that she then sells in various markets. She also has a stand near the hospital where she sells beverages. Leonidas needs a loan of 1,000 Sols which will be used to buy carbonated drinks, milk and paper. She dreams of her children finishing their studies and being able to get ahead. Click Here to see her previous loan.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy carbonated drinks, milk and paper.

loans.name: Nely

texts.es:
Nely es socia del Banco Comunal Morenita Huamanga.
Nely es casada, tiene 20 años y 2 hijos, Nely vende comida de manera ambulatoria cerca de los mercados del centro de la ciudad de Ayacucho, actividad que realiza por las mañana, además Nelly por las noches vende salchipollos en el parque enace. 
Nely necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, papa, huevo.
Los sueños de Nely son tener casa propia, brindar una buena educación y comida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Nely is a member of the communal bank group “Morenita Huamanga”. She is 20 years old, married and has 2 children. Nely is a traveling food vendor in the markets near the center of Ayacucho. She works from the markets every morning and also sells salchipollos (chicken & sausages) in the evenings at Enace Park.

Nely needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy rice, potatoes and eggs. She dreams of having her own home and providing a good education and food for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, potatoes and eggs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For making and selling food

loans.name: Eda

texts.en:
Eda C. and her husband, Crispeno, started a hog fattening and fruit tray weaving business four years ago. These businesses evolved from raising one piglet and selling fish! Though profit from their businesses is fairly good, Eda needs help growing her business since all of her family's daily expenses, including expenses for the education of her children, need to be covered.

To be able to accomplish her goal of increasing her profit, Eda decided to joining ASHI in 2007. The loans she requested then have been used to finance her hog and fish businesses. Eda has had two previous loans. However the growth she is dreaming of has yet to be reached, and she needs more business capital. She is now requesting a much larger amount to be able to buy more piglets and to finance a business weaving fruit trays using twigs. With these businesses, Eda hopes to be able to have more savings to help with her dream of buying a motorcycle to be used by her husband to sell fish. With her income, Eda is hoping to send all her children to college and have them graduate and have good careers.

loans.use: To finance a pig raising and fruit tray weaving business

loans.name: Ninita

texts.en:
Ninita N. is from the village of San Jose in Camiguin. She is 50 years old. Ninita is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Ninita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Ninita has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ninita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ninita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand product offering. Ninita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Ninita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: El Triangulo 1 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the group coordinator of the Banco de Esperanza (Bank of Hope) El Triangulo (The Triangle). Her story is representative of both her group and of Esperanza's Haitian (many of whom have recently immigrated to the DR) and Dominican clients. The group is based in Puerto Plata, a small developing city with limited access to running water and unreliable electricity. She lives with her husband in a rented house with wooden walls, a tin roof and cement floors. 

Maria came to Esperanza for a loan that would allow her to grow her business by buying more products to sell. She plans to buy various items to sell including: kitchen utensils, sheets, curtains, cosmetics, silver jewelry, and other accessories. She has more than six years of experience and has successfully paid back five loans in the past. Her loans have helped her support her family and have allowed her to offer help to others that live in her community.

loans.use: Purchasing items to sell such as: cooking utensils, sheets, curtains, cosmetics, silver jewelry, and other accessories

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es: La señora Maruja, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen del Rosario”,  Distrito de Bellavista, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 46 años y es madre de 06 hijos, 01 que aun depende de ella.Su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 le permitió aperturar su negocio de venta de bebidas gasificadas, para lo cual cuenta con un local muy bien acondicionado, tiene gran acogida entre sus clientes. En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio que le da muchas satisfacciones personales, familiares y económicas.  Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000.00 comprará diferentes gaseoas en tamaños y sabores, para así satisfacer a sus clientes.Se siente una mujer luchadora e independiente, gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos, salio adelante junto con su familia y hoy esta en mejores condiciones y estabilidad económica, ya que sus ventas se incrementan día a día.
texts.en:
Maruja is a member of the "Virgen del Rosario" communal bank located in the Bellavista District, San Martin Department. She is 46 years old, single, and the mother of 6 children, one of whom is still dependent on her. Her first loan of 300 new soles allowed her to open her soft drink sales business for which she has a well stocked store which is well regarded by her customers. She is still involved in this work which gives her much personal, family and economic satisfaction. With this current 3000 new sol loan she intends to purchase soft drinks in various sizes and flavors to better serve her customers. She feels that she is a fighter and independent and, thanks to the support from Manuela Ramos, together with her family, has gotten ahead in life and currently enjoys better living conditions and economic stability thanks to her ever increasing sales.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase inventory..

loans.name: Ahmad Sha Group

texts.en:
There are three members in this group led by A. Sha.They requested a group loan 42,000 Afghani.

A. Sha is a married man with four children: three daughters and one son. Two daughters are married, one daughter is in class six, and his son is a university student. A. Sha has a laundry and has taken the loan to purchase necessary materials for his business to make his business grow.

A. Sabor, who is a single boy, has a general store. There are six members in his family and he is the only person who supports them.

Malleha wants to take a loan for her tailoring business in her house. She wants to buy three new machines for her business and bring a new change to her business.

They are very happy with this loan in Afghanistan which improves their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials for his laundry

loans.name: Rivas Cusihuallpa

texts.es:
La socia G. pertenece al banco comunal “SIEMPRE ADELANTE”, es natural de la ciudad del Cusco.

La socia tiene 46 años de edad, es casada, tiene tres hijos dos mujeres y un varón.

Ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con el trabajo de atender su pequeño negocio de venta frutas que ofrece al por mayor y menor en el mercado “Virgen Asunta” de la ciudad del Cusco. 

La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio de venta de frutas.    
 
La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
G., 46, is a member of the "SIEMPRE ADELANTE" communal bank; she is from the city of Cusco. She is married and has three children: two girls and one boy. She alternates her domestic chores with tending to her small, wholesale and retail, fruit selling business which she has in Cusco's "Virgen Asunta" market. She needs financing to increase working capital in her fruit vending business. She is grateful for the opportunity given by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital in her fruit vending business.

loans.name: Diana

texts.es:
La Sra. Matías O. Diana tiene 44 años de edad, su casa es de material noble en la parte de adelante con techo de caña ubicada en el Centro Poblado Rosario de Yauca del caserio de Lujaraja. Su actividad es la venta de ropa, plástico y/u otro, desde hace 3 años, el negocio esta ubicado en su domicilio, también recorre la zona de Santiago, Pachacutec y Pueblo nuevo. sus ventas son al contado y a crédito a personal de fundos.Es madre soltera y una mujer emprendedora.Su sueño es llegar a ser una gran empresaria en la venta de ropa, juguetes, plásticos, etc.
Su negocio es su principal fuente de ingresos que le permite educar a sus 4 hijos, comprar sus bienes y construir su casita que fue afectada por el terremoto del 2007. Solicita crédito para invertir en ropa, juguetes y plástico; para la temporada de navidad.
texts.en:
Sra. Diana Matías O. is 44 years old and lives in a house built of solid materials, including a roof made of reeds. Her home is located in the central village of Rosario de Yauca in the region of Lujaraja. Diana has been selling clothing, plastics, and other items for three years. She operates her business out of her home, but she also travels to Santiago, Pachacutec, and Pueblo Nuevo. Her sales are made on a cash or credit basis. She is a single mother and enterprising woman. Her dream is to become a successful entrepreneur selling clothes, toys, plastics, and other products.

Her business is the main source of income for educating her four children. She purchased her own property and constructed a house that was affected by the 2007 earthquake. Diana is requesting a loan to buy clothing, toys, and plastics to sell for the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Acquire merchandise to sell for the Christmas season

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita V. is a 67 year old widow woman who lives in the village of Brgy Palaka, Pulupandan Negros Occidenta. She earns her living by operating a "sari-sari" general store. Nenita has four adult aged children who have their own families.  They don't forget to help their mother in terms of financial assistance.

Nenita joined NWTF-Project  Dungganon in 1998 to improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase her family income by engaging in her general store business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 15,000.

Nenita is a member in good standing.  Her previous loan of Php 15,000 funded the operations of her general store and it has had a positive impact on her business and family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 18th cycle loan of Php 20,000 to support her general store. Nenita is works hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.
-------------------------------------
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros  Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of  thousands of women through Project <i>Dungganon</i> (a Hiligaynon  word that means <u>Honorable</u>). Through the alleviation program,  NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to  achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path  that will ultimately make them <i>Dungganon</i> - a title of esteem  that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through  a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for general store.

loans.name: Yanapasiñani Group

texts.es:
Venta D. dulces, venta D. material escolar, venta D. juguetes, venta D. cosméticos, venta D. verduras y venta D. comida son los negocios que tienen las integrantes D. L. Asociación Comunal YanapaS., que significa nos ayudaremos, ellas se reúnen en el Centro Focal Los Andes.
Cesar Y. D. 26 años se dedica a vender dulces en L. calle Argentina, Beatriz S. D. 37 años también venD. dulces en L. zona D. Río Seco, hace 10 años.
Todas necesitan el préstamo, una vez más, para seguir invirtiendo en sus negocios y crecer día a día.
texts.en:
Sales of candies, school supplies, toys, cosmetics, vegetables, and food are the businesses operated by the members of the YanapaS. Communal Association. Their name means, “We will help ourselves.” They meet at the Los Andes regional center of Pro Mujer. Cesar Y., 26, sells candies on Argentina Street. Beatriz S., 37, also sells candies, in the Río Seco area, and has done so for ten years. They all need this loan to, once again, invest in their businesses and grow day by day.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Kanha

texts.en: Mrs. Kanha K. is 27 years old and lives in Ta Reab Doun village, Kandal province. She is a mother of two children, both of whom are too young to study or work. She and her husband, Mr. Sokhann Chhann (pictured right), are fish sellers at the local village market. In order to sell their fish door to door, Mrs. Kanha K. is asking for a loan to buy a motorbike. With the rest of the loan, she will buy more fish to increase her business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for door-to-door fish selling

loans.name: Glendis Ivelia

texts.es:
En el Municipio de Cinco Pinos, Departamento de Chinandega, la señora Glendis P. es propietaria de su propia pulpería donde vende los productos tales como: arroz, frijoles, azúcar, pan, aceite entre otros.
Esta solicitando un credito para invertirlo en la compra de los productos tales como: arroz, frijoles, azúcar, pan, aceite entre otros, con el propósito de surtir su pulpería para generar ingresos para el bienestar de su familia y seguir adelante con el negocio.
texts.en:
In the municipality of Cinco Pinos, Chinandega Department, Glendis P. owns her own general store, selling products such as rice, beans, sugar, bread, and oil. She requests a loan to invest in buying commodities such as rice, beans, sugar, bread, and oil, to stock her store and generate income for her family’s well being and to continue her business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy items such as school supplies, display cases, and grains

loans.name: Yi

texts.en:
Mrs. Yi H. is a 44-year-old widow with four children, one of whom is employed in a transport company, two are fishermen, and the other one is a student in the local school. This family lives in Ping Pong village, Takeo province.  
              
Mrs. Yi H. is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare field for cultivating rice. She now faces a problem because she does not have enough money to support her farming. Thus, she is now requesting 1,000,000 KHR from the Kiva partner, AMK, to buy gasoline, pesticide and to hire a farm laborer to help with her farming.

loans.use: To buy gasoline, pesticide and hire farm labor

loans.name: Pe

texts.en:
Pe C. is a 47-year-old farmer and father. He was blessed with five kids, two of whom are married while the other three are single. One of his sons is a taxi driver. His wife, Chean Orn, is 45 and works in the farming business. 

Pe C. inherited the farmland where he and his wife grow different kinds of crops from his grandmother. In additional, he breeds a few pigs in his pigpen. 

Pe C. is taking out his loan to mend and refurbish his existing motorcycle which is very old and broken down.

loans.use: To mend and refurbish his existing motorcycle

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran is 40-year-old lady. She lives with her family in a city called Borewala, in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

Sugran is a vigorous lady. She runs her own sewing business. She learnt the sewing skills from her mother. She has been managing this business for more than 15 years. Now she has become an expert and can sew designer and non-designer dresses very easily. She does this work to cover the expenses of her family.

Sugran is applying for a loan to buy wheat to expand her husband’s wheat-selling business. She has five other ladies in her loan group. Khursheedan and Hanifan and Sakina each want a loan to buy timber for their timber-selling businesses. Meena wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Zahida parveen wants a loan to buy fruit for her fruit-selling business.

loans.use: To buy wheat to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose sells firewood and also supplies soup items to retailers at their business places. She also sells spiritual items which are used for prayers by some Christians. She has been in this trade for many years now. Firewood is used for cooking in this part of the world; some people see it as an alternative to kerosene as it is faster to cook with.

Due to an increase in demand for firewood, Rose is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more firewood and soup items to sell. This, she said, will reduce her cost price and her transportation costs to market and so will increase her profit. This will also enable her to serve her customers better and help her to care for her family.

Rose is 54 years old and is married with four children. She and her family lives in Lagos State. She says thank you to all lenders for assisting her.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood and soup items to sell

loans.name: Roberto Antonio

texts.es:
El señor  Roberto Antonio R. U., vive con su esposa en el Barrio Medardo Andino,  ellos tienen 4 hijos que están casados, la familia se dedica a la agricultura desde hace 12 años y fue gracias a su esfuerzo propio que comenzaron sus días en este rubro.

Uno de los problemas que más los aflige,  es el robo de la producción que afecta sus ganancias, dentro de los planes que tiene para la producción está la introducción de nuevos cultivos, que se consuman en masa, antes de llevar acabo esto, solicitan préstamo para la compra de materiales agricolas, tales como fertilizantes, insumos vegetativos y semillas, con esto esperan que la producción se les multiplique, y de la misma manera las utilidades para la reinversión ya sea en su negocio o en proyectos personales y familiares que favorezcan al mejoramiento económico-social de toda la familia.
texts.en:
Roberto Antonio R. U. lives with his wife in the Medardo Andino neighborhood. They have four children who are married. The family has been in farming for the past 12 years; they started out in this line of work thanks to their own efforts. One of the problems that most distresses them is the loss of some of their production to theft; this affects their earnings. Among their plans for the future is introducing new crops that are mass consumed. Prior to doing this, however, they need funds to buy farm supplies like: fertilizers, seed and other supplies that they hope will increase their crop yields and their profits to be reinvested either into the business or to cover personal and family expenses that will improve the entire family’s socio-economic standing.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more jeans to sell

loans.name: Colomba

texts.es: Colomba H. Vda. D. V. D. 50 años D. edad, resiD. en Jiquilisco, ubicado en el departamento D. Usulután. Colomba es una mujer muy trabajadora, la cual trabaja arduamente por sacar adelante por si sola a sus dos hijos, quienes estudian, y el mayor le ayuda con el negocio en sus tiempos libre. Colomba desD. muy pequeña se dedica a vender todo tipo D. mariscos tales como: camarones, pescado, lonja y otras más, en el negocio se dedicaba a ayudarle a su madre a vender el productos, lo cual ha sido una gran experiencia porque en la actualidad ella se sigue dedicando a este trabajo, el cual le permite contar con las ganancias necesarias para sostener a su hogar, sobretodo desD. que su esposo falleció, ya que después D. esto Colomba debió trabajar más duro para seguir adelante. Ella solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. pescado, y así mismo incluir en el negocio otros tipos D. mariscos para poder obtener más clientes, su negocio cuenta con muy buena ubicación, debido a que se encuentra en el mercado D. Jiquilisco.
texts.en:
Colomba H. Vda. D. V., 50, lives in Jiquilisco, Usulután department. Colomba is a very hard-working woman who works hard to support her two children, who are students, by herself; her eldest son helps her with her business in his spare time. Since she was very young, Colomba has sold all kinds of seafood like shrimp and fish; she used to help her mother and this was great experience for her because now she is in the same kind of business that provides her with profits to support her home, especially since her husband died, because since then Colomba has had to work even harder in order to continue forward. She is asking for funds to buy larger amounts of fish so that she can incluD. other kinds of seafood in her inventory thereby securing more customers. Her business enjoys a good location because it’s in Jiquilisco’s market.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seafood.

loans.name: Peris

texts.en:
Peris has been operating a green grocery for 5 years. She has one child who goes to school, and her husband is a businessman. In addition she runs another business selling cosmetics and CDs as her other source of income. Ladies and all the villagers are her potential customers. 

With the Kshs 30,000 she would like to build a permanent stall and sell her products retail, at the market and door to door. She cites high competition as her major challenge in the business. 

Peris hopes to sell her products wholesale in future. She decided to join Yehu so as to get loan and expand her business. Peris owns a home with electricity but no piped water, her greatest monthly expense being food.

loans.use: To build a stall to sell her goods

loans.name: Marie N'ke

texts.fr: Née en 1960, S. Marie N'Ke est mariée à KOUTADO Lazare, un douanier à la retraite. Marie N'Ke est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé. Mais le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge, en plus de leur enfant. Il y a près de dix sept ans que Marie N'Ke vit au quartier Cocotomey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Marie N'Ke vit ensemble avec ses deux enfants et son mari. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Marie N'Ke n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Marie N'Ke vend des friperies à son domicile, ce qui lui procure des revenus l'aidant à subvenir à ses besoins. Marie N'Ke achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est la deuxième fois que Marie N'Ke sollicite auprès de ALIDé un concours financier, en vue d'élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Marie N'Ke a bien remboursé le premier crédit qu'elle avait obtenu de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1960, S. Marie N'Ke is married to KOUTADO Lazare, a retired customs agent. Marie N'Ke is the mother of one child who is enrolled in school. However, the couple is responsible for another child besides their biological child. For almost 17 years Marie N'Ke has been living in the Cocotomey district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Marie N'Ke lives together with her two children and her husband. The couple share the responsibility for supporting their family. Marie N'Ke only attended elementary school. For about 12 years, Marie N'Ke has been selling used clothing out of her home, which brings in income that helps her to support herself. She buys her goods at Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. This is the second time that she is requesting a loan from ALIDé, aimed at expanding her business and better satisfying her clientele. She correctly reimbursed her first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of two bales of used clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy materials to build a restraining wall

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn B. is from the village of Medallo, Sapang Dalaga. She is 35 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Roselyn grows assorted crops and sells them in the local community. Roselyn has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Roselyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. Roselyn has successfully repaid her previous loan of 12,000 PHP. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Roselyn is requesting a new loan of 10,500 PHP which she will use to complete the construction of her house. This loan is Roselyn's  ninth loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template to help Field Partners continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house completion

loans.name: Taciana

texts.en:
Taciana S. is from the city of Prenza, Tangub City. She is 50 years old. Taciana is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Taciana owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products, such as shampoo, soap, and noodles in the local community. Taciana has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Taciana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Taciana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Taciana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Taciana from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Filomena

texts.es:
La Señora Filomena es socia del Banco Comunal “Señor de Huanca II”  ubicado en el distrito de Cabanillas, provincia de San Román y departamento de Puno, tiene 52 años de edad, de estado civil  soltera y tiene 03 hijos, (02 de  ellos son independientes),  la señora no cuenta con estudios.

La señora Filomena esta trabajando con Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 04 años,  nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo recibido de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, pudo incrementar su capital para su negocio de venta de Comida.

Con este nuevo crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles comprará más alimentos para la venta de comida  y así poder vender mas cantidad.

Su sueño para el futuro es tener restaurante.

Lo que mas le gusta de su Banco Comunal son las reuniones con las socias y lo que gana con los ahorros.

Foto: notese en la foto un poco oscura ya que se encuentra dentro de un toldo donde vende sus alimentos en forma ambulatoria.
texts.en:
Sra. Filomena is a member of the Communal Bank “Señor de Huanca II”, which is located in the District of Cabanillas, San Román Province, Department of Puno. She is 52 years old, single, and has three children (two of whom are independent). Filomenta did not attend school.

Sra. Filomena has been working with Manuela Ramos for four years. She says the first loan she received was in the amount of 300 PEN, which she used to increase the capital for her food business.

With this new loan of 300 PEN, Filomena will buy more ingredients for preparing food which will help generate more sales. Her dream for the future is to open a restaurant. What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank are the meetings with the other members and the earnings from her savings.

Please Note: The photograph is a bit dark since it was taken inside the tent where she sells food as a street vendor.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for food preparation

loans.name: Annah Mutile

texts.en:
Annah opened her clothes shop in Naivasha town a year ago, and she finds it profitable.  She is 36 years old, married to Patel Shilovele and they have three children.

She was introduce to KADET Ltd. by her friend and this will be her first loan of 30,000 Kenyan Shillings with KADET, which she plans to use to buy more clothes to sell.

Annah hopes to grow her clothes shop, selling all types of clothing to her customers who reside in Naivasha.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen
texts.en: Carmen

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs and household goods.

loans.name: Yenny Alexandra

texts.es:
Yenny de 25 años, vive en una zona periurbana llamada Fortín y caracterizada por sus caminos de tierra y montañas, tiene una pequeña tienda de víveres. 

Comenzó hace 7 meses con la tienda para poder mantener a su familia y ayudar a su esposo que es operador de maquina, vende bebidas, dulces, enlatados y otros víveres en su tienda a un bajo costo. Trabaja desde las 06h00am hasta las 21h00pm todos los días.  No quiere tener hijos hasta que tenga un buen sustento económico para que ellos tengan todo lo que necesiten. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar aceite, arroz y bebidas para surtir mas su negocio ya que recién comienza y quiere que todos sus clientes tengan todo lo que necesitan. En el futuro quiere agrandar su tienda y construir su casa de cemento.
texts.en:
Yenny, age 25, lives in a suburb named Fortín which is characterized by it's dirt roads and mountains.  She has a small general store.  

She began the store 7  months ago in order to support her family and help her husband who is a machine operator.  She sells beverages, sweets,  canned goods and other provisions in her store at a reduced cost.  She works from 6AM to 9PM every day.  She does not want to have children until they have a good economic standard of living so that they have everything that they need.  

With the loan she wants to buy oil, rice and beverages to better supply her business that she recently started and to satisfy the demands of all of her clients so they have everything that they need.  In the future she wants to enlarge her store and to build a house of cement.

loans.use: To buy oil, rice and beverages for resale in her store.

loans.name: Nury Alejandra

texts.en:
Nury is a member of the Communal Bank group "Great Power," located in the district of Ilave, in the province of Collao, and the department of Puno. She is 47 years old and is a single mother of one child. She has not completed her higher education. 

Nury has worked with Manuela Ramos for five years. The first loan she got was for 500 PEN to increase the merchandise in her business, which is selling wine, coca, sweets, and other products. It is a business that varies according to the season.  During Christmas she sells fireworks, chocolates, wine, cake, and other things.  During Carnaval, Mother's Day, and national festivals, she also sells other types of products.

She is currently asking for a new loan of 2,500 PEN, to invest in her business.  Her dream is to have a business filled with products, and for her son to know his father. 

Her favorite thing about the Communal Bank is the unity.

loans.use: Invest in her business selling wine, coca, and other products

loans.name: Karla Maria

texts.es:
Karla Maria tiene 1 hijo a su cargo, tiene 22 años, ya que ella es una madre soltera y busca obtener ingresos para su hogar. El se dedica a la venta de comida. Desde hace 2 años, que tiene este negocio la mayoría de sus clientes aprecian la buena comida que realiza por lo que es muy importante para ella ofrecer buena calidad. Su préstamo inicial es para incrementar el capital de su negocio de granos básicos, juegos, aceite, verduras entre otras cosas.
Su sueño es que su negocio se convierta en un restaurante en donde ofrezca una gran variedad de comidas. Pues ahorita se acercan épocas muy buenas.
texts.en: Karla Maria is 22 years old and has one child.  She is a single mother seeking to earn an income for her household.  She has been selling food for a living for the past 2 years and the majority of her customers appreciate the good quality food that she offers.  This is her first loan and she will use it to buy basic grains, juice, oil, vegetables, etc.  Her dream is to one day convert her business into a restaurant where she will offer a wide variety of foods.   Right now, things are going well for her.

loans.use: To purchase grains, juice, vegetables, etc for her business

loans.name: Vanessa Claire

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanessa Claire L. is from the Barangay of Maloro, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old, married to Isagani L., and is blessed with 2 children, one is of school age and the other is still an infant. 

To make a living, she is presently engaged in operating a fast food eatery business. She is also receiving support from her husband as an overseas seaman. She’s been engaged in this fast food eatery business for the past 8 years.  She earns an amount of not less than Php 2,500.00 a day. 

In 2008, Vanessa Claire joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vanessa Claire is an active member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, and has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php 150,000.00.   She is now requesting a loan of Php 50,000.00 as her 8th loan, which will be used as additional working capital for her existing fast food eatery business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family -- especially in meeting their basic needs, and to use for future savings, loan repayments, her children’s education, and for possible business expansions.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Working capital for food eatery business

loans.name: Yadira Graciela

texts.es:
En la ciudadela Nueva Portoviejo de la  ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Nueva Portoviejo.
 
Encontramos a la señora Yadira, tiene 31 años de edad, está casada y tiene dos hijos  de cuatro y dos años que son la luz de su vida comenta. Ella participo en un concurso de alta costura a nivel provincial en este año en el que logro el primer lugar.
 
Tiene un pequeño taller de costura donde desde hace muchos años se dedica a coser ropa de todo tipo de ropa (vestidos quinceañeras, de novias, y otras). Pero dice que le encanta hacer ropa para niños, trabaja a base de pedidos de personas particulares y también elabora ropa para un almacén en el centro de la ciudad, trabaja con la ayuda de una persona a la cual le paga un sueldo mensual.

Está en el Banco Comunal cuatro años y está muy contenta ya que le han ayudado mucho. Este nuevo crédito lo va utilizar para comprar telas y otros materiales para la costura. Sus sueños son tener un taller más grande y un almacén en el centro de la ciudad donde también pueda vender sus obras.
texts.en:
Every fortnight the members of the 'Nueva Portoviejo' community bank meet in the Nueva Portoviejo district of the city of Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí, which has been known for many years as the city of the royal tamarind trees.

Here we meet 31 year-old Yadira who is married and has two children, aged 4 and 2, who are the light of her life.  Yadira competed in a haute couture competition at province level this year and she won first place.

Yadira has a small dressmaking workshop where she has been sewing all kinds of clothes (15th birthday dresses, bridal gowns, etc.) for many years.  However, she says that she loves making children's clothes.  She works on orders from individuals and also makes clothes for a store in the city center.  She works with the help of another person who she pays a monthly salary.

Yadira has been a member of her community bank for four years and she is very happy because it has helped her a lot.  She will use this new loan to buy fabric and other materials for her dressmaking business.  Her dreams are to have a bigger workshop in the city center where she can also sell her clothes.

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread, zippers, buttons, etc.

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed is a young man from Tulkarem, Ahmed and his brothers own a carpentry shop where they make furniture such as tables, chairs, beds, doors and windows. 

Ahmed took a loan from the FATEN branch in Tulkarem (where he appears in the picture) to buy wood and make more furniture. Ahmed and his brothers always try to meet deadlines and ensure the best furniture quality.

loans.use: To purchase wood for furniture making

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira O. is from the village of Bacnor East, Burgos, Isabela. She is 50 years old. Elvira is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she provides motorcycle transportation services. Elvira has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5000 Php a month for these activities.

In 2006, Elvira joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other motorcycle accessories. 

Elvira is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to repair the motorcycle for better service. This will be her 9th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair her vehicle for better service

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
42-year-old Marites is from the town of San Francisco. She is married and has 5 children, aged 17, 15, 13, 9 and 4. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marites works hard to build her business.

Marites joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, medicines and fertilizers. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marites from CEVI. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, medicines and fertilizers

loans.name: Grover

texts.es:
Es un señor trabajador, cuenta con una familia reducida, sus hijos se encuentran estudiando en el colegio, el Sr Grover O. tiene una peluquería con mucho sacrificio ya que  ha sufrido mucho en su vida, pero el pudo sobrellevar sus problemas y la situación en que se encuentra.
 
Actualmente hizo cursos de nivelación en un  institutito y quiere  seguir  superándose , el  paso por y nos solicito un crédito para capital de trabajo, donde fue aceptado ya que por  referencia de sus vecinos siempre ha sido una persona responsable y trabajadora.
texts.en:
This is a very hard-working man. He has a small family and his children are in school. Mr. Grover O. has a beauty salon which he has obtained through great sacrifice, since he has suffered greatly in his life. However, he has been able to endure his problems and his situation.

He has just finished courses in an institute and he wants to continue bettering himself. He came to us and requested a loan for working capital, and he was accepted because, according to his neighbours' reference, he has always been a responsible and hard-working person.

loans.use: working capital for his hair salon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en: Narcisa M. is from the village of Centro 2. She is 55 years old. Narcisa is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Narcisa raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Narcisa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Narcisa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Narcisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Narcisa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the third loan taken out by Narcisa from ASKI.
